contentrichtext.text: A '''Zenith number''' is a special type of [[toll-free telephone number]] in the United States and Canada that was introduced prior to the development of [[Wide Area Telephone Service|WATS]] toll-free service. It allows a [[calling party]] to call the number's owner at no charge by dialing the [[Switchboard operator|operator]] and requesting the specified Zenith number. In some places the name '''Enterprise''' or the letters '''WX''' are used. Some organizations continue to keep their Zenith numbers - as of 2006, the [[California Highway Patrol]] continues to use the same single number it has for decades, ''Zenith 1-2000''.<ref>[http://massis.lcs.mit.edu/telecom-archives/TELECOM_Digest_Online2006-1/1390.html Remembering Old Zenith Numbers]</ref> But with the low cost of incoming WATS service, Zenith numbers have nearly disappeared and telephone companies in most service areas no longer offer new Zenith numbers.{{fact|date=May 2012}} The Zenith number was listed in local telephone directories in each community from which a business desired to receive calls. The operator handled the call by looking up the regular number corresponding to the Zenith number, typically in a paper book kept at the switchboard, and completing the call as if it were a collect call to the regular number.<ref>{{cite news|title=Your special ZENITH number: ZENITH phone service gets you out-of-town customers without costly branch offices|publisher=The Spokesman-Review, Spokane WA|page=7|format=advertisement|author=Pacific Telephone|date=Friday August 21, 1959|url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1314&dat=19590821&id=xJwzAAAAIBAJ&sjid=y-cDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3027,1885047 }}</ref> The numbers were originally advertised in the 1950s, an era in which direct-dial numbers were commonly published with [[telephone exchange names]] followed by digits (such as "[[PEnnsylvania 6-5000]]"). The reason the name Zenith is used is that the letter Z did not, at the time that the service started, appear on the telephone dial, thus necessitating that the caller dial the operator.{{fact|date=May 2012}} ==Examples== * [[Ontario Provincial Police]] Detachment Search 50-000{{fact|date=May 2012}} * Ambulance Dispatchers - Ontario Zenith 80-000 {{fact|date=May 2012}} * Town of [[Winchester, Ontario]] ambulance dispatcher Zenith 9000{{fact|date=May 2012}} ==References== <references /> {{Telecommunications}} [[Category:Telephone numbers]]
